     2→import { ref, onMounted, onUnmounted } from 'vue'
     3→import type { Ref } from 'vue'
     4→
     5→interface ScrollAnimationOptions {
     6→  threshold?: number
     7→  rootMargin?: string
     8→  once?: boolean // Only trigger animation once
     9→}
    10→
    11→/**
    12→ * Basic scroll animation composable with IntersectionObserver
    13→ * Adds 'visible' class to elements when they enter viewport
    14→ */
    15→export const useScrollAnimation = (options: ScrollAnimationOptions = {}) => {
    16→  const {
    17→    threshold = 0.1,
    18→    rootMargin = '0px',
    19→    once = true,
    20→  } = options
    21→
    22→  let observer: IntersectionObserver | null = null
    23→
    24→  const observeElement = (element: Element) => {
    25→    if (!element) return
    26→
    27→    // Immediately observe the element
    28→    observer?.observe(element)
    29→  }
    30→
    31→  const unobserveElement = (element: Element) => {
    32→    if (!element) return
    33→    observer?.unobserve(element)
    34→  }
    35→
    36→  onMounted(() => {
    37→    // Create simple intersection observer
    38→    observer = new IntersectionObserver(
    39→      (entries) => {
    40→        entries.forEach((entry) => {
    41→          if (entry.isIntersecting) {
    42→            // Add 'visible' class when element enters viewport
    43→            entry.target.classList.add('visible')
    44→
    45→            // Optionally stop observing after first trigger
    46→            if (once) {
    47→              observer?.unobserve(entry.target)
    48→            }
    49→          } else if (!once) {
    50→            // Remove class if observing continuously
    51→            entry.target.classList.remove('visible')
    52→          }
    53→        })
    54→      },
    55→      { threshold, rootMargin }
    56→    )
    57→  })
    58→
    59→  onUnmounted(() => {
    60→    observer?.disconnect()
    61→    observer = null
    62→  })
    63→
    64→  return {
    65→    observeElement,
    66→    unobserveElement,
    67→  }
    68→}
    69→
    70→/**
    71→ * Advanced scroll animation with ref-based visibility tracking
    72→ * Returns reactive visibility state and target ref
    73→ */
    74→export function useScrollAnimationRef(
    75→  threshold: number = 0.2,
    76→  rootMargin: string = '0px',
    77→  once: boolean = true
    78→) {
    79→  const isVisible = ref(false)
    80→  const targetRef: Ref<HTMLElement | null> = ref(null)
    81→  let observer: IntersectionObserver | null = null
    82→
    83→  onMounted(() => {
    84→    if (!targetRef.value) return
    85→
    86→    observer = new IntersectionObserver(
    87→      (entries) => {
    88→        entries.forEach((entry) => {
    89→          if (entry.isIntersecting) {
    90→            isVisible.value = true
    91→
    92→            // Optionally stop observing after first trigger
    93→            if (once && observer && targetRef.value) {
    94→              observer.unobserve(targetRef.value)
    95→            }
    96→          } else if (!once) {
    97→            isVisible.value = false
    98→          }
    99→        })
   100→      },
   101→      {
   102→        threshold,
   103→        rootMargin,
   104→      }
   105→    )
   106→
   107→    observer.observe(targetRef.value)
   108→  })
   109→
   110→  onUnmounted(() => {
   111→    if (observer && targetRef.value) {
   112→      observer.unobserve(targetRef.value)
   113→      observer.disconnect()
   114→    }
   115→  })
   116→
   117→  return {
   118→    targetRef,
   119→    isVisible,
   120→  }
   121→}
   122→
   123→/**
   124→ * Staggered scroll animations for list items
   125→ * Triggers animations sequentially with delay
   126→ */
   127→export function useStaggeredScrollAnimation(
   128→  staggerDelay: number = 100,
   129→  threshold: number = 0.2
   130→) {
   131→  const containerRef: Ref<HTMLElement | null> = ref(null)
   132→  let observer: IntersectionObserver | null = null
   133→
   134→  onMounted(() => {
   135→    if (!containerRef.value) return
   136→
   137→    observer = new IntersectionObserver(
   138→      (entries) => {
   139→        entries.forEach((entry) => {
   140→          if (entry.isIntersecting) {
   141→            const children = Array.from(entry.target.children)
   142→
   143→            // Trigger staggered animations
   144→            children.forEach((child, index) => {
   145→              setTimeout(() => {
   146→                child.classList.add('visible')
   147→              }, index * staggerDelay)
   148→            })
   149→
   150→            // Stop observing after trigger
   151→            if (observer && containerRef.value) {
   152→              observer.unobserve(containerRef.value)
   153→            }
   154→          }
   155→        })
   156→      },
   157→      {
   158→        threshold,
   159→      }
   160→    )
   161→
   162→    observer.observe(containerRef.value)
   163→  })
   164→
   165→  onUnmounted(() => {
   166→    if (observer && containerRef.value) {
   167→      observer.unobserve(containerRef.value)
   168→      observer.disconnect()
   169→    }
   170→  })
   171→
   172→  return {
   173→    containerRef,
   174→  }
   175→}
   176→
   177→/**
   178→ * Parallax scroll effect composable
   179→ * Returns reactive scroll progress (0-1) for element
   180→ */
   181→export function useParallaxScroll(speed: number = 0.5) {
   182→  const targetRef: Ref<HTMLElement | null> = ref(null)
   183→  const scrollProgress = ref(0)
   184→
   185→  const updateParallax = () => {
   186→    if (!targetRef.value) return
   187→
   188→    const rect = targetRef.value.getBoundingClientRect()
   189→    const viewportHeight = window.innerHeight
   190→
   191→    // Calculate progress (0 when element enters bottom, 1 when it exits top)
   192→    const progress = (viewportHeight - rect.top) / (viewportHeight + rect.height)
   193→    scrollProgress.value = Math.max(0, Math.min(1, progress))
   194→
   195→    // Apply transform
   196→    const translateY = (scrollProgress.value - 0.5) * 100 * speed
   197→    targetRef.value.style.transform = `translateY(${translateY}px)`
   198→  }
   199→
   200→  onMounted(() => {
   201→    window.addEventListener('scroll', updateParallax, { passive: true })
   202→    updateParallax() // Initial calculation
   203→  })
   204→
   205→  onUnmounted(() => {
   206→    window.removeEventListener('scroll', updateParallax)
   207→  })
   208→
   209→  return {
   210→    targetRef,
   211→    scrollProgress,
   212→  }
   213→}

## Context & Problem Statement

The Eye On Idea website aims to showcase premium web consultancy capabilities through its own UX/UI. The current implementation suffers from:

1. **Animation system fragmentation** - 4 competing patterns, 2 of which are unused dead code
2. **Inconsistent feature distribution** - advanced effects appear on some pages but not others
3. **Stagger timing chaos** - increments vary from 50ms to 200ms with no rhythm
4. **Component duplication** - Hero, CTA, PackageCard, Breadcrumb components repeated 2-4x
5. **Glass morphism overuse** - applied broadly where selective use would create stronger hierarchy
6. **No unified design language** - the site feels like multiple micro-sites assembled together

### User Decisions Made
- **Magnetic buttons**: Rethink as scale-only (no position shift), hero CTAs only
- **TextReveal**: Extend to ALL page heroes for brand consistency
- **ParticleWaves 3D**: Home only (remove from About)
- **Scope**: Broader redesign including component architecture and glass morphism refinement
- **Glass morphism**: Reduce to key focal areas, research complementary design patterns (minimalism, selective brutalism)
- **Priority**: All pages treated equally

## Research Findings

### Glass Morphism: When to Use & When Not To

**Use glass morphism for** (sources: [NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/), [IxDF](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/topics/glassmorphism)):
- Establishing visual hierarchy over complex/gradient backgrounds
- Overlay components (modals, contextual menus, floating panels)
- Navigation elements that float over content
- Featured/spotlight cards that need to pop
- Virtual/mixed-reality-style interfaces

**Do NOT use glass morphism for** (sources: [NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/), [Axess Lab](https://axesslab.com/glassmorphism-meets-accessibility-can-frosted-glass-be-inclusive/)):
- Every card or container (dilutes the effect, hurts readability)
- Components over simple, single-color backgrounds (no visual payoff)
- Text-heavy content areas (transparency hurts reading flow)
- Small, repeated elements like tags or badges
- Mobile-first interfaces where `backdrop-filter` has performance cost

**Key principle**: "Use glass for only a few key elements. Stick to navigation bars, primary buttons, or important cards, not every component on the screen." ([NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/))

### Minimalism + Glass: Complementary Patterns

Glass morphism naturally pairs with minimalism - both emphasize clean lines and intentional use of space. The approach: minimalist solid surfaces as the default, glass as the accent for elements that need visual hierarchy.

**Sources**: [Alpha Efficiency](https://alphaefficiency.com/glassmorphism-ui), [Ramotion](https://www.ramotion.com/blog/what-is-glassmorphism/)

### Nordic/Scandinavian Design Alignment

Scandinavian design emphasizes:
- Functional minimalism with generous white space
- Natural, muted color palettes (earth tones, wood, stone)
- Clean typography with strong hierarchy
- Intentionality - every element earns its place
- Human-centered, authentic design over decoration

This aligns well with reducing glass morphism to intentional accent points and adopting cleaner, more minimal sections elsewhere.

**Sources**: [Awwwards](https://www.awwwards.com/), [WebFX](https://www.webfx.com/blog/web-design/modern-web-design/), [Colorlib](https://colorlib.com/wp/portfolio-design-trends/)

### 2025-2026 Agency Portfolio Trends

- Asymmetric layouts with generous white space
- Nature-distilled color palettes (muted earthy tones)
- Mix of digital polish with authentic/handmade elements
- Bold typography as a design element itself
- Intentional animation (motion with purpose, not decoration)

**Sources**: [Designmodo](https://designmodo.com/web-design-trends/), [Wix Trends](https://www.wix.com/blog/web-design-trends), [Framer](https://www.framer.com/blog/web-design-trends/)

### Vue 3 Component Architecture

Key patterns for reducing duplication:
- **Base components with slots**: `BaseHero`, `BaseCTA` with content slots
- **Composable extraction**: Shared logic in `use*` functions
- **Options object pattern**: Composables accept config objects for flexibility
- **Provide/inject**: Share state deeply without prop drilling

**Sources**: [Vue.js Docs](https://vuejs.org/guide/reusability/composables.html), [Vue Mastery](https://www.vuemastery.com/blog/coding-better-composables-1-of-5/), [Michael Thiessen](https://michaelnthiessen.com/composable-patterns-in-vue)

## Phase 1: Audit Decisions

Every task in this phase requires discussion before proceeding to implementation.

### Task 1.1 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Magnetic Effect Rethink
- [x] Design scale-only proximity effect for hero CTAs

**Decision**: Scale amount `1.02` (subtle), no box-shadow expansion. Scale-only, no position shift. Hero CTAs only.

---

### Task 1.2 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Animation System Consolidation
- [x] Agree on single animation approach

**Decision**: Standardize on `v-motion` + `useAccessibleMotion`. No edge case concerns. Migrate all 10 manual IntersectionObserver components.

---

### Task 1.3 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Stagger Timing Standards
- [x] Establish stagger rhythm constants

**Decision**: Approved as proposed. `STAGGER_CARD: 100ms`, `STAGGER_TEXT: 60ms`, `STAGGER_ICON: 120ms`.

---

### Task 1.4 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Glass Morphism Reduction Strategy
- [x] Define which elements keep glass vs which become solid/minimal

**Decision**: Approved as proposed. CTA sections keep glass. Header, hero overlays, spotlight cards, modals, color toggle, and CTAs retain glass. Content cards, pricing, forms, info cards, footer, and legal pages switch to solid/minimal.

---

### Task 1.5 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Complementary Design Pattern for Non-Glass Areas
- [x] Define the visual language for solid/minimal areas

**Decision**: Mix of Option A (Clean Minimalism) and Option B (Warm Minimalism with Texture). Nordic-aligned clean surfaces with generous spacing and bold typography, combined with subtle background textures and slight shadow depth for warmth.

---

### Task 1.6 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Component Architecture: Base Components
- [x] Agree on which base components to extract

**Decision**: BaseHero as a slot-based full component. Home Hero stays standalone (too unique). Home CTA stays standalone (unique layout). All other base components approved as proposed.

---

### Task 1.7 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - CustomCursor: Confirm Removal
- [x] Confirm CustomCursor stays unmounted

**Decision**: Delete `CustomCursor.vue`. Keep `useCursorFollow` composable for Values shine effect.

     2→
     3→> **Created**: 2026-02-14
     4→> **Status**: Phase 1 Complete - Starting Phase 2
     5→> **Scope**: Animation consistency, component architecture refactoring, glass morphism refinement, design pattern cohesion
     6→> **Estimated files affected**: ~25 modified, 2-4 deleted, 3-5 new base components
     7→

     9→

    48→---
    49→
    50→## Context & Problem Statement
    51→
    52→The Eye On Idea website aims to showcase premium web consultancy capabilities through its own UX/UI. The current implementation suffers from:
    53→
    54→1. **Animation system fragmentation** - 4 competing patterns, 2 of which are unused dead code
    55→2. **Inconsistent feature distribution** - advanced effects appear on some pages but not others
    56→3. **Stagger timing chaos** - increments vary from 50ms to 200ms with no rhythm
    57→4. **Component duplication** - Hero, CTA, PackageCard, Breadcrumb components repeated 2-4x
    58→5. **Glass morphism overuse** - applied broadly where selective use would create stronger hierarchy
    59→6. **No unified design language** - the site feels like multiple micro-sites assembled together
    60→
    61→### User Decisions Made
    62→- **Magnetic buttons**: Rethink as scale-only (no position shift), hero CTAs only
    63→- **TextReveal**: Extend to ALL page heroes for brand consistency
    64→- **ParticleWaves 3D**: Home only (remove from About)
    65→- **Scope**: Broader redesign including component architecture and glass morphism refinement
    66→- **Glass morphism**: Reduce to key focal areas, research complementary design patterns (minimalism, selective brutalism)
    67→- **Priority**: All pages treated equally
    68→

    78→| `v-motion` + `useAccessibleMotion` | About (Hero, Story, Values, Founder, Location, CTA), News components | Declarative `v-motion` directives | **Active - 11+ components** |
    79→| `useScrollAnimation` composable | None | 4 exported functions, 0 imports | **Dead code** |

   123→
   124→---
   125→
   126→## Research Findings
   127→
   128→### Glass Morphism: When to Use & When Not To
   129→
   130→**Use glass morphism for** (sources: [NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/), [IxDF](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/topics/glassmorphism)):
   131→- Establishing visual hierarchy over complex/gradient backgrounds
   132→- Overlay components (modals, contextual menus, floating panels)
   133→- Navigation elements that float over content
   134→- Featured/spotlight cards that need to pop
   135→- Virtual/mixed-reality-style interfaces
   136→
   137→**Do NOT use glass morphism for** (sources: [NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/), [Axess Lab](https://axesslab.com/glassmorphism-meets-accessibility-can-frosted-glass-be-inclusive/)):
   138→- Every card or container (dilutes the effect, hurts readability)
   139→- Components over simple, single-color backgrounds (no visual payoff)
   140→- Text-heavy content areas (transparency hurts reading flow)
   141→- Small, repeated elements like tags or badges
   142→- Mobile-first interfaces where `backdrop-filter` has performance cost
   143→
   144→**Key principle**: "Use glass for only a few key elements. Stick to navigation bars, primary buttons, or important cards, not every component on the screen." ([NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/))
   145→
   146→### Minimalism + Glass: Complementary Patterns
   147→
   148→Glass morphism naturally pairs with minimalism - both emphasize clean lines and intentional use of space. The approach: minimalist solid surfaces as the default, glass as the accent for elements that need visual hierarchy.
   149→
   150→**Sources**: [Alpha Efficiency](https://alphaefficiency.com/glassmorphism-ui), [Ramotion](https://www.ramotion.com/blog/what-is-glassmorphism/)
   151→
   152→### Nordic/Scandinavian Design Alignment
   153→
   154→Scandinavian design emphasizes:
   155→- Functional minimalism with generous white space
   156→- Natural, muted color palettes (earth tones, wood, stone)
   157→- Clean typography with strong hierarchy
   158→- Intentionality - every element earns its place
   159→- Human-centered, authentic design over decoration
   160→
   161→This aligns well with reducing glass morphism to intentional accent points and adopting cleaner, more minimal sections elsewhere.
   162→
   163→**Sources**: [Awwwards](https://www.awwwards.com/), [WebFX](https://www.webfx.com/blog/web-design/modern-web-design/), [Colorlib](https://colorlib.com/wp/portfolio-design-trends/)
   164→
   165→### 2025-2026 Agency Portfolio Trends
   166→
   167→- Asymmetric layouts with generous white space
   168→- Nature-distilled color palettes (muted earthy tones)
   169→- Mix of digital polish with authentic/handmade elements
   170→- Bold typography as a design element itself
   171→- Intentional animation (motion with purpose, not decoration)
   172→
   173→**Sources**: [Designmodo](https://designmodo.com/web-design-trends/), [Wix Trends](https://www.wix.com/blog/web-design-trends), [Framer](https://www.framer.com/blog/web-design-trends/)
   174→
   175→### Vue 3 Component Architecture
   176→
   177→Key patterns for reducing duplication:
   178→- **Base components with slots**: `BaseHero`, `BaseCTA` with content slots
   179→- **Composable extraction**: Shared logic in `use*` functions
   180→- **Options object pattern**: Composables accept config objects for flexibility
   181→- **Provide/inject**: Share state deeply without prop drilling
   182→
   183→**Sources**: [Vue.js Docs](https://vuejs.org/guide/reusability/composables.html), [Vue Mastery](https://www.vuemastery.com/blog/coding-better-composables-1-of-5/), [Michael Thiessen](https://michaelnthiessen.com/composable-patterns-in-vue)
   184→
   185→---
   186→
   187→## Phase 1: Audit Decisions
   188→
   189→Every task in this phase requires discussion before proceeding to implementation.
   190→
   191→### Task 1.1 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Magnetic Effect Rethink
   192→- [x] Design scale-only proximity effect for hero CTAs
   193→
   194→**Decision**: Scale amount `1.02` (subtle), no box-shadow expansion. Scale-only, no position shift. Hero CTAs only.
   195→

   197→
   198→### Task 1.2 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Animation System Consolidation
   199→- [x] Agree on single animation approach
   200→
   201→**Decision**: Standardize on `v-motion` + `useAccessibleMotion`. No edge case concerns. Migrate all 10 manual IntersectionObserver components.
   202→

   204→
   205→### Task 1.3 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Stagger Timing Standards
   206→- [x] Establish stagger rhythm constants
   207→
   208→**Decision**: Approved as proposed. `STAGGER_CARD: 100ms`, `STAGGER_TEXT: 60ms`, `STAGGER_ICON: 120ms`.

   212→### Task 1.4 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Glass Morphism Reduction Strategy

   215→**Decision**: Approved as proposed. CTA sections keep glass. Header, hero overlays, spotlight cards, modals, color toggle, and CTAs retain glass. Content cards, pricing, forms, info cards, footer, and legal pages switch to solid/minimal.
   216→

   218→
   219→### Task 1.5 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Complementary Design Pattern for Non-Glass Areas
   220→- [x] Define the visual language for solid/minimal areas
   221→
   222→**Decision**: Mix of Option A (Clean Minimalism) and Option B (Warm Minimalism with Texture). Nordic-aligned clean surfaces with generous spacing and bold typography, combined with subtle background textures and slight shadow depth for warmth.

<script setup lang="ts">
import { ref, onMounted, onUnmounted } from "vue";

const { t, tm } = useI18n();

// Scroll animation
const sectionRef = ref<HTMLElement | null>(null);
const isVisible = ref(false);

onMounted(() => {
  if (!sectionRef.value) return;

  const observer = new IntersectionObserver(
    (entries) => {
      entries.forEach((entry) => {
        if (entry.isIntersecting) {
          isVisible.value = true;
          observer.disconnect();
        }
      });
    },
    { threshold: 0.15 },
  );

  observer.observe(sectionRef.value);

  onUnmounted(() => {
    observer.disconnect();
  });
});

// Package data
const packages = [
  {
    key: "launch",
    variant: "default" as const,
    popular: false,
  },
  {
    key: "growth",
    variant: "featured" as const,
    popular: true,
  },
  {
    key: "platform",

## Context & Problem Statement

The Eye On Idea website aims to showcase premium web consultancy capabilities through its own UX/UI. The current implementation suffers from:

1. **Animation system fragmentation** - 4 competing patterns, 2 of which are unused dead code
2. **Inconsistent feature distribution** - advanced effects appear on some pages but not others
3. **Stagger timing chaos** - increments vary from 50ms to 200ms with no rhythm
4. **Component duplication** - Hero, CTA, PackageCard, Breadcrumb components repeated 2-4x
5. **Glass morphism overuse** - applied broadly where selective use would create stronger hierarchy
6. **No unified design language** - the site feels like multiple micro-sites assembled together

### User Decisions Made
- **Magnetic buttons**: Rethink as scale-only (no position shift), hero CTAs only
- **TextReveal**: Extend to ALL page heroes for brand consistency
- **ParticleWaves 3D**: Home only (remove from About)
- **Scope**: Broader redesign including component architecture and glass morphism refinement
- **Glass morphism**: Reduce to key focal areas, research complementary design patterns (minimalism, selective brutalism)
- **Priority**: All pages treated equally

---

## Current State Audit

### Animation System Fragmentation

| Pattern | Used In | Mechanism | Status |

| Manual IntersectionObserver + CSS class | Home (Hero, About, CTA, Services), Contact (Hero, Info, Form), Services (Hero), Legal, Policies | `isVisible` ref + `.animate-in` CSS | **Active - 10+ components** |
| `v-motion` + `useAccessibleMotion` | About (Hero, Story, Values, Founder, Location, CTA), News components | Declarative `v-motion` directives | **Active - 11+ components** |
| `useScrollAnimation` composable | None | 4 exported functions, 0 imports | **Dead code** |
| `useStaggeredScrollAnimation` | None | Container-level stagger | **Dead code** |

## Research Findings

### Glass Morphism: When to Use & When Not To

**Use glass morphism for** (sources: [NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/), [IxDF](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/topics/glassmorphism)):
- Establishing visual hierarchy over complex/gradient backgrounds
- Overlay components (modals, contextual menus, floating panels)
- Navigation elements that float over content
- Featured/spotlight cards that need to pop
- Virtual/mixed-reality-style interfaces

**Do NOT use glass morphism for** (sources: [NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/), [Axess Lab](https://axesslab.com/glassmorphism-meets-accessibility-can-frosted-glass-be-inclusive/)):
- Every card or container (dilutes the effect, hurts readability)
- Components over simple, single-color backgrounds (no visual payoff)
- Text-heavy content areas (transparency hurts reading flow)
- Small, repeated elements like tags or badges
- Mobile-first interfaces where `backdrop-filter` has performance cost

**Key principle**: "Use glass for only a few key elements. Stick to navigation bars, primary buttons, or important cards, not every component on the screen." ([NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/))

### Minimalism + Glass: Complementary Patterns

Glass morphism naturally pairs with minimalism - both emphasize clean lines and intentional use of space. The approach: minimalist solid surfaces as the default, glass as the accent for elements that need visual hierarchy.

**Sources**: [Alpha Efficiency](https://alphaefficiency.com/glassmorphism-ui), [Ramotion](https://www.ramotion.com/blog/what-is-glassmorphism/)

### Nordic/Scandinavian Design Alignment

Scandinavian design emphasizes:
- Functional minimalism with generous white space
- Natural, muted color palettes (earth tones, wood, stone)
- Clean typography with strong hierarchy
- Intentionality - every element earns its place
- Human-centered, authentic design over decoration

This aligns well with reducing glass morphism to intentional accent points and adopting cleaner, more minimal sections elsewhere.

**Sources**: [Awwwards](https://www.awwwards.com/), [WebFX](https://www.webfx.com/blog/web-design/modern-web-design/), [Colorlib](https://colorlib.com/wp/portfolio-design-trends/)

### 2025-2026 Agency Portfolio Trends

- Asymmetric layouts with generous white space
- Nature-distilled color palettes (muted earthy tones)
- Mix of digital polish with authentic/handmade elements
- Bold typography as a design element itself
- Intentional animation (motion with purpose, not decoration)

**Sources**: [Designmodo](https://designmodo.com/web-design-trends/), [Wix Trends](https://www.wix.com/blog/web-design-trends), [Framer](https://www.framer.com/blog/web-design-trends/)

### Vue 3 Component Architecture

Key patterns for reducing duplication:
- **Base components with slots**: `BaseHero`, `BaseCTA` with content slots
- **Composable extraction**: Shared logic in `use*` functions
- **Options object pattern**: Composables accept config objects for flexibility
- **Provide/inject**: Share state deeply without prop drilling

**Sources**: [Vue.js Docs](https://vuejs.org/guide/reusability/composables.html), [Vue Mastery](https://www.vuemastery.com/blog/coding-better-composables-1-of-5/), [Michael Thiessen](https://michaelnthiessen.com/composable-patterns-in-vue)

**Decision**: Approved as proposed. CTA sections keep glass. Header, hero overlays, spotlight cards, modals, color toggle, and CTAs retain glass. Content cards, pricing, forms, info cards, footer, and legal pages switch to solid/minimal.

### Task 1.5 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Complementary Design Pattern for Non-Glass Areas
- [x] Define the visual language for solid/minimal areas

**Decision**: Mix of Option A (Clean Minimalism) and Option B (Warm Minimalism with Texture). Nordic-aligned clean surfaces with generous spacing and bold typography, combined with subtle background textures and slight shadow depth for warmth.

## Research Findings

### Glass Morphism: When to Use & When Not To

**Use glass morphism for** (sources: [NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/), [IxDF](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/topics/glassmorphism)):
- Establishing visual hierarchy over complex/gradient backgrounds
- Overlay components (modals, contextual menus, floating panels)
- Navigation elements that float over content
- Featured/spotlight cards that need to pop
- Virtual/mixed-reality-style interfaces

**Do NOT use glass morphism for** (sources: [NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/), [Axess Lab](https://axesslab.com/glassmorphism-meets-accessibility-can-frosted-glass-be-inclusive/)):
- Every card or container (dilutes the effect, hurts readability)
- Components over simple, single-color backgrounds (no visual payoff)
- Text-heavy content areas (transparency hurts reading flow)
- Small, repeated elements like tags or badges
- Mobile-first interfaces where `backdrop-filter` has performance cost

**Key principle**: "Use glass for only a few key elements. Stick to navigation bars, primary buttons, or important cards, not every component on the screen." ([NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/))

### Minimalism + Glass: Complementary Patterns

Glass morphism naturally pairs with minimalism - both emphasize clean lines and intentional use of space. The approach: minimalist solid surfaces as the default, glass as the accent for elements that need visual hierarchy.

**Sources**: [Alpha Efficiency](https://alphaefficiency.com/glassmorphism-ui), [Ramotion](https://www.ramotion.com/blog/what-is-glassmorphism/)

### Nordic/Scandinavian Design Alignment

Scandinavian design emphasizes:
- Functional minimalism with generous white space
- Natural, muted color palettes (earth tones, wood, stone)
- Clean typography with strong hierarchy
- Intentionality - every element earns its place
- Human-centered, authentic design over decoration

This aligns well with reducing glass morphism to intentional accent points and adopting cleaner, more minimal sections elsewhere.

**Sources**: [Awwwards](https://www.awwwards.com/), [WebFX](https://www.webfx.com/blog/web-design/modern-web-design/), [Colorlib](https://colorlib.com/wp/portfolio-design-trends/)

### 2025-2026 Agency Portfolio Trends

- Asymmetric layouts with generous white space
- Nature-distilled color palettes (muted earthy tones)
- Mix of digital polish with authentic/handmade elements
- Bold typography as a design element itself
- Intentional animation (motion with purpose, not decoration)

**Sources**: [Designmodo](https://designmodo.com/web-design-trends/), [Wix Trends](https://www.wix.com/blog/web-design-trends), [Framer](https://www.framer.com/blog/web-design-trends/)

### Vue 3 Component Architecture

Key patterns for reducing duplication:
- **Base components with slots**: `BaseHero`, `BaseCTA` with content slots
- **Composable extraction**: Shared logic in `use*` functions
- **Options object pattern**: Composables accept config objects for flexibility
- **Provide/inject**: Share state deeply without prop drilling

**Sources**: [Vue.js Docs](https://vuejs.org/guide/reusability/composables.html), [Vue Mastery](https://www.vuemastery.com/blog/coding-better-composables-1-of-5/), [Michael Thiessen](https://michaelnthiessen.com/composable-patterns-in-vue)

# Eye On Idea - UX Streamlining & Design Consistency Plan

> **Created**: 2026-02-14
> **Status**: Phases 1-3 Complete - Starting Phase 4
> **Scope**: Animation consistency, component architecture refactoring, glass morphism refinement, design pattern cohesion
> **Estimated files affected**: ~25 modified, 2-4 deleted, 3-5 new base components

---

## How to Use This Plan

### Tracking Progress
- Each task has a checkbox `[ ]`. Mark as `[x]` when complete.
- Tasks marked **[DISCUSS]** require user input before any code is written.
- Tasks within a phase should be completed in order unless noted otherwise.
- You may pause after any completed task and resume later - note the Phase and Task number.

### Collaboration Rules
1. **No content, text, or information shall be created without prior discussion and explicit agreement.**
2. At every **[DISCUSS]** checkpoint, the implementer must ask the user questions to determine wants, needs, and preferences.
3. Any fictitious information, placeholder copy, or assumed content is strictly prohibited without prior agreement.
4. This is a collaboration - insights emerge from questions and debate. Challenge assumptions.
5. When resuming work, re-read this plan and confirm the current phase/task before proceeding.

### Progress Legend
- `[ ]` - Not started
- `[x]` - Complete
- `[~]` - In progress / partially done
- `[!]` - Blocked (needs discussion or dependency)

---

## Table of Contents

1. [Context & Problem Statement](#context--problem-statement)
2. [Current State Audit](#current-state-audit)
3. [Research Findings](#research-findings)
4. [Phase 1: Audit Decisions (All DISCUSS)](#phase-1-audit-decisions)

## Context & Problem Statement

The Eye On Idea website aims to showcase premium web consultancy capabilities through its own UX/UI. The current implementation suffers from:

1. **Animation system fragmentation** - 4 competing patterns, 2 of which are unused dead code
2. **Inconsistent feature distribution** - advanced effects appear on some pages but not others
3. **Stagger timing chaos** - increments vary from 50ms to 200ms with no rhythm
4. **Component duplication** - Hero, CTA, PackageCard, Breadcrumb components repeated 2-4x
5. **Glass morphism overuse** - applied broadly where selective use would create stronger hierarchy
6. **No unified design language** - the site feels like multiple micro-sites assembled together

### User Decisions Made
- **Magnetic buttons**: Rethink as scale-only (no position shift), hero CTAs only
- **TextReveal**: Extend to ALL page heroes for brand consistency
- **ParticleWaves 3D**: Home only (remove from About)
- **Scope**: Broader redesign including component architecture and glass morphism refinement
- **Glass morphism**: Reduce to key focal areas, research complementary design patterns (minimalism, selective brutalism)
- **Priority**: All pages treated equally

---

## Current State Audit

## Research Findings

### Glass Morphism: When to Use & When Not To

**Use glass morphism for** (sources: [NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/), [IxDF](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/topics/glassmorphism)):
- Establishing visual hierarchy over complex/gradient backgrounds
- Overlay components (modals, contextual menus, floating panels)
- Navigation elements that float over content
- Featured/spotlight cards that need to pop
- Virtual/mixed-reality-style interfaces

**Do NOT use glass morphism for** (sources: [NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/), [Axess Lab](https://axesslab.com/glassmorphism-meets-accessibility-can-frosted-glass-be-inclusive/)):
- Every card or container (dilutes the effect, hurts readability)
- Components over simple, single-color backgrounds (no visual payoff)
- Text-heavy content areas (transparency hurts reading flow)
- Small, repeated elements like tags or badges
- Mobile-first interfaces where `backdrop-filter` has performance cost

**Key principle**: "Use glass for only a few key elements. Stick to navigation bars, primary buttons, or important cards, not every component on the screen." ([NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/))

### Minimalism + Glass: Complementary Patterns

Glass morphism naturally pairs with minimalism - both emphasize clean lines and intentional use of space. The approach: minimalist solid surfaces as the default, glass as the accent for elements that need visual hierarchy.

**Sources**: [Alpha Efficiency](https://alphaefficiency.com/glassmorphism-ui), [Ramotion](https://www.ramotion.com/blog/what-is-glassmorphism/)

### Nordic/Scandinavian Design Alignment

Scandinavian design emphasizes:
- Functional minimalism with generous white space
- Natural, muted color palettes (earth tones, wood, stone)
- Clean typography with strong hierarchy
- Intentionality - every element earns its place
- Human-centered, authentic design over decoration

This aligns well with reducing glass morphism to intentional accent points and adopting cleaner, more minimal sections elsewhere.

**Sources**: [Awwwards](https://www.awwwards.com/), [WebFX](https://www.webfx.com/blog/web-design/modern-web-design/), [Colorlib](https://colorlib.com/wp/portfolio-design-trends/)

### 2025-2026 Agency Portfolio Trends

- Asymmetric layouts with generous white space
- Nature-distilled color palettes (muted earthy tones)
- Mix of digital polish with authentic/handmade elements
- Bold typography as a design element itself
- Intentional animation (motion with purpose, not decoration)

**Sources**: [Designmodo](https://designmodo.com/web-design-trends/), [Wix Trends](https://www.wix.com/blog/web-design-trends), [Framer](https://www.framer.com/blog/web-design-trends/)

### Vue 3 Component Architecture

Key patterns for reducing duplication:
- **Base components with slots**: `BaseHero`, `BaseCTA` with content slots
- **Composable extraction**: Shared logic in `use*` functions
- **Options object pattern**: Composables accept config objects for flexibility
- **Provide/inject**: Share state deeply without prop drilling

**Sources**: [Vue.js Docs](https://vuejs.org/guide/reusability/composables.html), [Vue Mastery](https://www.vuemastery.com/blog/coding-better-composables-1-of-5/), [Michael Thiessen](https://michaelnthiessen.com/composable-patterns-in-vue)

**Decision**: Standardize on `v-motion` + `useAccessibleMotion`. No edge case concerns. Migrate all 10 manual IntersectionObserver components.

**Decision**: Approved as proposed. CTA sections keep glass. Header, hero overlays, spotlight cards, modals, color toggle, and CTAs retain glass. Content cards, pricing, forms, info cards, footer, and legal pages switch to solid/minimal.

---

### Task 1.5 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Complementary Design Pattern for Non-Glass Areas
- [x] Define the visual language for solid/minimal areas

**Decision**: Mix of Option A (Clean Minimalism) and Option B (Warm Minimalism with Texture). Nordic-aligned clean surfaces with generous spacing and bold typography, combined with subtle background textures and slight shadow depth for warmth.

# Eye On Idea - UX Streamlining & Design Consistency Plan

> **Created**: 2026-02-14
> **Status**: Phases 1-4 Complete - Starting Phase 5
> **Scope**: Animation consistency, component architecture refactoring, glass morphism refinement, design pattern cohesion
> **Estimated files affected**: ~25 modified, 2-4 deleted, 3-5 new base components

---

## How to Use This Plan

### Tracking Progress
- Each task has a checkbox `[ ]`. Mark as `[x]` when complete.
- Tasks marked **[DISCUSS]** require user input before any code is written.
- Tasks within a phase should be completed in order unless noted otherwise.
- You may pause after any completed task and resume later - note the Phase and Task number.

### Collaboration Rules
1. **No content, text, or information shall be created without prior discussion and explicit agreement.**
2. At every **[DISCUSS]** checkpoint, the implementer must ask the user questions to determine wants, needs, and preferences.
3. Any fictitious information, placeholder copy, or assumed content is strictly prohibited without prior agreement.
4. This is a collaboration - insights emerge from questions and debate. Challenge assumptions.
5. When resuming work, re-read this plan and confirm the current phase/task before proceeding.

### Progress Legend
- `[ ]` - Not started
- `[x]` - Complete
- `[~]` - In progress / partially done
- `[!]` - Blocked (needs discussion or dependency)

---

## Table of Contents

1. [Context & Problem Statement](#context--problem-statement)
2. [Current State Audit](#current-state-audit)
3. [Research Findings](#research-findings)
4. [Phase 1: Audit Decisions (All DISCUSS)](#phase-1-audit-decisions)
5. [Phase 2: Foundation - Animation Infrastructure](#phase-2-foundation)
6. [Phase 3: Component Architecture Refactoring](#phase-3-component-architecture)
7. [Phase 4: Glass Morphism Refinement](#phase-4-glass-morphism-refinement)
8. [Phase 5: Global Animation Consistency](#phase-5-global-animation-consistency)
9. [Phase 6: Page-Specific Enhancements](#phase-6-page-specific-enhancements)
10. [Phase 7: Performance & Accessibility Audit](#phase-7-performance--accessibility)
11. [Phase 8: Final Review & Testing](#phase-8-final-review--testing)
12. [Appendix: File Inventory](#appendix-file-inventory)

---

## Context & Problem Statement

The Eye On Idea website aims to showcase premium web consultancy capabilities through its own UX/UI. The current implementation suffers from:

1. **Animation system fragmentation** - 4 competing patterns, 2 of which are unused dead code
2. **Inconsistent feature distribution** - advanced effects appear on some pages but not others
3. **Stagger timing chaos** - increments vary from 50ms to 200ms with no rhythm
4. **Component duplication** - Hero, CTA, PackageCard, Breadcrumb components repeated 2-4x
5. **Glass morphism overuse** - applied broadly where selective use would create stronger hierarchy
6. **No unified design language** - the site feels like multiple micro-sites assembled together

### User Decisions Made
- **Magnetic buttons**: Rethink as scale-only (no position shift), hero CTAs only
- **TextReveal**: Extend to ALL page heroes for brand consistency
- **ParticleWaves 3D**: Home only (remove from About)
- **Scope**: Broader redesign including component architecture and glass morphism refinement
- **Glass morphism**: Reduce to key focal areas, research complementary design patterns (minimalism, selective brutalism)
- **Priority**: All pages treated equally

---

## Current State Audit

### Animation System Fragmentation

| Pattern | Used In | Mechanism | Status |
|---------|---------|-----------|--------|
| Manual IntersectionObserver + CSS class | Home (Hero, About, CTA, Services), Contact (Hero, Info, Form), Services (Hero), Legal, Policies | `isVisible` ref + `.animate-in` CSS | **Active - 10+ components** |
| `v-motion` + `useAccessibleMotion` | About (Hero, Story, Values, Founder, Location, CTA), News components | Declarative `v-motion` directives | **Active - 11+ components** |
| `useScrollAnimation` composable | None | 4 exported functions, 0 imports | **Dead code** |
| `useStaggeredScrollAnimation` | None | Container-level stagger | **Dead code** |

### Stagger Timing Inconsistency

| Component | Base | Increment | Notes |
|-----------|------|-----------|-------|
| Home AboutSection cards | 100ms | +100ms | |
| Home ServicesSection | 100ms | +100ms then +200ms jump | Inconsistent within itself |
| Contact Info cards | 100ms | +50ms | Different increment |
| About Values | 350ms | +120ms | Late start |
| About Story | 300ms | +150ms | Late start |
| Services CMS cards | 50ms | +50ms | Fast |
| TextReveal words | 60-80ms | varies | Nearly consistent |
| StrokeDraw icons | 80-150ms | varies | Inconsistent |

### Advanced Feature Distribution Matrix

| Feature | Home | About | Services | Contact | Process | Legal/Policies | News |
|---------|:----:|:-----:|:--------:|:-------:|:-------:|:--------------:|:----:|
| TextReveal | Yes | Yes | Yes | No | No | No | No |
| ParticleWaves 3D | Yes | Yes | - | - | - | - | - |
| v-magnetic | Yes | Yes | Yes | - | - | - | - |
| StrokeDraw | Yes | Yes | - | Yes | Yes | - | - |
| Parallax | - | Yes | - | - | - | - | - |
| TiltCard | - | Yes | - | - | - | - | - |
| LiquidGlass | - | Yes | - | - | - | - | - |
| AnimatedCounter | - | - | Yes | - | - | - | - |
| SectionNav | - | - | Yes | - | - | - | - |
| BeforeAfter | - | - | Yes | - | - | - | - |
| Skeleton loading | - | - | - | - | - | - | Yes |

### Component Duplication Analysis

| Pattern | Instances | Lines Duplicated | Files |
|---------|-----------|-----------------|-------|
| Hero sections | 6 components | ~400 lines shared | `home/HeroSection`, `about/Hero`, `services/Hero`, `contact/Hero`, `process/Hero`, `news/Hero` |

**Estimated reduction**: 1,500-2,000 lines of code through consolidation.

---

## Research Findings

### Glass Morphism: When to Use & When Not To

**Use glass morphism for** (sources: [NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/), [IxDF](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/topics/glassmorphism)):
- Establishing visual hierarchy over complex/gradient backgrounds
- Overlay components (modals, contextual menus, floating panels)
- Navigation elements that float over content
- Featured/spotlight cards that need to pop
- Virtual/mixed-reality-style interfaces

**Do NOT use glass morphism for** (sources: [NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/), [Axess Lab](https://axesslab.com/glassmorphism-meets-accessibility-can-frosted-glass-be-inclusive/)):
- Every card or container (dilutes the effect, hurts readability)
- Components over simple, single-color backgrounds (no visual payoff)
- Text-heavy content areas (transparency hurts reading flow)
- Small, repeated elements like tags or badges
- Mobile-first interfaces where `backdrop-filter` has performance cost

**Key principle**: "Use glass for only a few key elements. Stick to navigation bars, primary buttons, or important cards, not every component on the screen." ([NNGroup](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/glassmorphism/))

### Minimalism + Glass: Complementary Patterns

Glass morphism naturally pairs with minimalism - both emphasize clean lines and intentional use of space. The approach: minimalist solid surfaces as the default, glass as the accent for elements that need visual hierarchy.

**Sources**: [Alpha Efficiency](https://alphaefficiency.com/glassmorphism-ui), [Ramotion](https://www.ramotion.com/blog/what-is-glassmorphism/)

### Nordic/Scandinavian Design Alignment

Scandinavian design emphasizes:
- Functional minimalism with generous white space
- Natural, muted color palettes (earth tones, wood, stone)
- Clean typography with strong hierarchy
- Intentionality - every element earns its place
- Human-centered, authentic design over decoration

This aligns well with reducing glass morphism to intentional accent points and adopting cleaner, more minimal sections elsewhere.

**Sources**: [Awwwards](https://www.awwwards.com/), [WebFX](https://www.webfx.com/blog/web-design/modern-web-design/), [Colorlib](https://colorlib.com/wp/portfolio-design-trends/)

### 2025-2026 Agency Portfolio Trends

- Asymmetric layouts with generous white space
- Nature-distilled color palettes (muted earthy tones)
- Mix of digital polish with authentic/handmade elements
- Bold typography as a design element itself
- Intentional animation (motion with purpose, not decoration)

**Sources**: [Designmodo](https://designmodo.com/web-design-trends/), [Wix Trends](https://www.wix.com/blog/web-design-trends), [Framer](https://www.framer.com/blog/web-design-trends/)

### Vue 3 Component Architecture

Key patterns for reducing duplication:
- **Base components with slots**: `BaseHero`, `BaseCTA` with content slots
- **Composable extraction**: Shared logic in `use*` functions
- **Options object pattern**: Composables accept config objects for flexibility
- **Provide/inject**: Share state deeply without prop drilling

**Sources**: [Vue.js Docs](https://vuejs.org/guide/reusability/composables.html), [Vue Mastery](https://www.vuemastery.com/blog/coding-better-composables-1-of-5/), [Michael Thiessen](https://michaelnthiessen.com/composable-patterns-in-vue)

---

## Phase 1: Audit Decisions

Every task in this phase requires discussion before proceeding to implementation.

### Task 1.1 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Magnetic Effect Rethink

**Decision**: Scale amount `1.02` (subtle), no box-shadow expansion. Scale-only, no position shift. Hero CTAs only.

### Task 1.2 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Animation System Consolidation

**Decision**: Standardize on `v-motion` + `useAccessibleMotion`. No edge case concerns. Migrate all 10 manual IntersectionObserver components.

### Task 1.3 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Stagger Timing Standards

### Task 1.4 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Glass Morphism Reduction Strategy

**Decision**: Approved as proposed. CTA sections keep glass. Header, hero overlays, spotlight cards, modals, color toggle, and CTAs retain glass. Content cards, pricing, forms, info cards, footer, and legal pages switch to solid/minimal.

---

### Task 1.5 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Complementary Design Pattern for Non-Glass Areas
- [x] Define the visual language for solid/minimal areas

**Decision**: Mix of Option A (Clean Minimalism) and Option B (Warm Minimalism with Texture). Nordic-aligned clean surfaces with generous spacing and bold typography, combined with subtle background textures and slight shadow depth for warmth.

---

### Task 1.6 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Component Architecture: Base Components

**Decision**: BaseHero as a slot-based full component. Home Hero stays standalone (too unique). Home CTA stays standalone (unique layout). All other base components approved as proposed.

**Decision**: Delete `CustomCursor.vue`. Keep `useCursorFollow` composable for Values shine effect.

### Task 1.9 ~~[DISCUSS]~~ DECIDED - Dead Code Inventory

# Eye On Idea - UX Streamlining & Design Consistency Plan

> **Created**: 2026-02-14
> **Status**: Phases 1-4 Complete - Starting Phase 5
> **Scope**: Animation consistency, component architecture refactoring, glass morphism refinement, design pattern cohesion
> **Estimated files affected**: ~25 modified, 2-4 deleted, 3-5 new base components

---

## How to Use This Plan

### Tracking Progress
- Each task has a checkbox `[ ]`. Mark as `[x]` when complete.
- Tasks marked **[DISCUSS]** require user input before any code is written.
- Tasks within a phase should be completed in order unless noted otherwise.
- You may pause after any completed task and resume later - note the Phase and Task number.

### Collaboration Rules
1. **No content, text, or information shall be created without prior discussion and explicit agreement.**
2. At every **[DISCUSS]** checkpoint, the implementer must ask the user questions to determine wants, needs, and preferences.
3. Any fictitious information, placeholder copy, or assumed content is strictly prohibited without prior agreement.
4. This is a collaboration - insights emerge from questions and debate. Challenge assumptions.
5. When resuming work, re-read this plan and confirm the current phase/task before proceeding.

### Progress Legend

- `[x]` - Complete
- `[~]` - In progress / partially done
- `[!]` - Blocked (needs discussion or dependency)

4. [Phase 1: Audit Decisions (All DISCUSS)](#phase-1-audit-decisions)

12. [Appendix: File Inventory](#appendix-file-inventory)

---

## Context & Problem Statement

The Eye On Idea website aims to showcase premium web consultancy capabilities through its own UX/UI. The current implementation suffers from:

1. **Animation system fragmentation** - 4 competing patterns, 2 of which are unused dead code
2. **Inconsistent feature distribution** - advanced effects appear on some pages but not others
3. **Stagger timing chaos** - increments vary from 50ms to 200ms with no rhythm
4. **Component duplication** - Hero, CTA, PackageCard, Breadcrumb components repeated 2-4x
5. **Glass morphism overuse** - applied broadly where selective use would create stronger hierarchy
6. **No unified design language** - the site feels like multiple micro-sites assembled together

### User Decisions Made
- **Magnetic buttons**: Rethink as scale-only (no position shift), hero CTAs only
- **TextReveal**: Extend to ALL page heroes for brand consistency
- **ParticleWaves 3D**: Home only (remove from About)
- **Scope**: Broader redesign including component architecture and glass morphism refinement
- **Glass morphism**: Reduce to key focal areas, research complementary design patterns (minimalism, selective brutalism)
- **Priority**: All pages treated equally

---

## Current State Audit

### Animation System Fragmentation

| Pattern | Used In | Mechanism | Status |
|---------|---------|-----------|--------|
| Manual IntersectionObserver + CSS class | Home (Hero, About, CTA, Services), Contact (Hero, Info, Form), Services (Hero), Legal, Policies | `isVisible` ref + `.animate-in` CSS | **Active - 10+ components** |
| `v-motion` + `useAccessibleMotion` | About (Hero, Story, Values, Founder, Location, CTA), News components | Declarative `v-motion` directives | **Active - 11+ components** |
| `useScrollAnimation` composable | None | 4 exported functions, 0 imports | **Dead code** |
| `useStaggeredScrollAnimation` | None | Container-level stagger | **Dead code** |

### Stagger Timing Inconsistency

| Component | Base | Increment | Notes |
|-----------|------|-----------|-------|
| Home AboutSection cards | 100ms | +100ms | |
| Home ServicesSection | 100ms | +100ms then +200ms jump | Inconsistent within itself |
| Contact Info cards | 100ms | +50ms | Different increment |
| About Values | 350ms | +120ms | Late start |
| About Story | 300ms | +150ms | Late start |
| Services CMS cards | 50ms | +50ms | Fast |
| TextReveal words | 60-80ms | varies | Nearly consistent |
| StrokeDraw icons | 80-150ms | varies | Inconsistent |

### Advanced Feature Distribution Matrix

| Feature | Home | About | Services | Contact | Process | Legal/Policies | News |
|---------|:----:|:-----:|:--------:|:-------:|:-------:|:--------------:|:----:|
| TextReveal | Yes | Yes | Yes | No | No | No | No |
| ParticleWaves 3D | Yes | Yes | - | - | - | - | - |

     5→ * Composable for accessible animations that respect user motion preferences

     7→ */
     8→export function useAccessibleMotion() {
     9→  // Check for reduced motion preference using VueUse core
    10→  const reducedMotionPreference = usePreferredReducedMotion();
    11→  const prefersReducedMotion = computed(() => reducedMotionPreference.value === "reduce");
    12→
    13→  /**
    14→   * Returns animation variant or static variant based on motion preference
    15→   * @param animationVariant - The full animation variant to use
    16→   * @param staticVariant - Optional static variant for reduced motion (defaults to visible state)
    17→   */
    18→  const variant = <T extends Record<string, any>>(
    19→    animationVariant: T,
    20→    staticVariant?: Partial<T>
    21→  ): T => {
    22→    if (prefersReducedMotion.value) {
    23→      // Return static variant (no animation)
    24→      return (staticVariant || animationVariant.visible || {}) as T;
    25→    }
    26→    return animationVariant;
    27→  };
    28→
    29→  return {
    30→    prefersReducedMotion,
    31→    variant,
    32→    animationPresets,
    33→  };

  prefersReducedMotion.value = window.matchMedia(
